title: Imaging
text:
Diving into imaging is a great experience. I have engaged in many imaging techniques, including light, fluorescence, laser scanning microscopy, as part of my work. I find immense joy in appreciating the aesthetic aspects of biology through the art of imaging. Feel free to explore my gallery for a visual journey into my work.









Sperm of Platynereis dumerilii labeled in orange pumpkin (nuclei) and olive (standard lissaminated morpholino)







Male and female of Platynereis dumerilirr







This is a photo of a regenerated anterior body of Syllis malaquini. In pink, S-phase cells, i.e. proliferating cells. Green: chaetae








Sperm of Platynereis dumerilii labeled in orange pumpkin (nuclei) and olive (standard lissaminated morpholino)
Male and female of Platynereis dumerilirr
This is a photo of a regenerated anterior body of Syllis malaquini. In pink, S-phase cells, i.e. proliferating cells. Green: chaetae

title: Comics
text: I have a passion for comics, and during my PhD, I began illustrating them to creatively convey my research findings. My aspiration is to craft a unique comic for each of my future publications whenever feasible. These comics aim to present the key insights from my research articles in an enjoyable and engaging manner. Rather than adhering to a strict publishing schedule, I let my creativity and current mindset guide me through the scientific storytelling process. Take a peek at the comics I’ve created thus far.

title: Welcome To My Website
text:
Welcome to my website! Here, you’ll discover my research on amazing worms that can regrow their whole bodies. I’ll also share my latest adventures in teaching, outreach, and sci-art. Let the journey begin, and may you find it both informative and enjoyable!

Anterior regeneration in Syllis malaquini. Green, chaetae. Pink, S-phase cells.

title: Research
text: Ranny studies regeneration and reproduction in marine segmented worms, or annelids. During her PhD, she explored the variability in regenerative abilities and its correlation with the evolutionary aspects of annelid reproductive modes. She used different tools to investigate regeneration in a group of annelids called syllids, including RNAseq, bioinformatics and immunohistochemestry. Currently, she interested in unraveling the mysteries of how these organisms harness their regenerative abilities to lead extended lifespans, manipulating the intricate regulation of reproduction in the process.What sets annelids apart from other highly regenerative organisms, such as planarians and cnidarians, is the absence of specialized stem cells dedicated to regeneration. This absence raises a compelling question: how do they achieve remarkable regenerative feats without relying on specific cell types? Unraveling this mystery holds the potential to manipulate regenerative processes in various cell types, including those found in vertebrates. The research sheds light on the fascinating world of annelid regeneration, opening avenues for broader applications in tissue regeneration and cellular differentiation.

title: Research
text:
Annelid diversity and evolution



Ranny has dedicated numerous years to the study of the diversity of polychaetes. Embarking on her scientific journey by collecting specimens from the mangroves of her hometown, Maranhão, Brazil, her initial venture into science involved taxonomical description of polychaetes. Having overseen two projects for Bachelors and a Masters degree, and through collaborative research set alongside, she has described 15 polychaete species.

title: About me
text:
I hail from São Luís, Maranhão, Brazil, boasting a rich heritage that spans Native Brazilian roots from the Guajajara tribe, alongside African and Iberian ancestry. From a tender age, my fascination with science took root. Eventually, I pursued my passion, becoming a biologist. During my undergraduate studies, I was introduced to a remarkable realm inhabited by creatures both delicate and conspicuous—polychaetes, which are marine segmented worms. I have navigated through various projects studying these worms, spanning taxonomy, ecology, systematics, reproduction, and ultimately, regeneration. Sometimes my adventures led me to the middle of a mangrove, collecting worms from the mud; sometimes, I found myself scuba diving in paradisiacal oceanic islands, and most times, I was on the lab bench, pipetting or counting segments.
During this exploration, I found out how amazing these worms are at regenerating, and I realized: this is my calling. Fascinated by the remarkable power of regeneration these worms possess, my research has become a quest to comprehend the mechanisms by which their cells proliferate and differentiate into any cell type, and how these mechanisms help worms to defy the passage of time and live indefinitely.
Although the work is nice, for a balanced life, I like to spend time with my family, I keep a fitness schedule for strenght, and I love dancing all styles: salsa, bachata, kizomba, all brazilian rithms (axe, funk, pisadinha) and yes, I’m also a pole dancer.

title: Ranny P. Ribeiro, PhD
text: I am currently a Postdoctoral Researcher in the Özpolat Lab at Washington University in St. Louis. My primary research interest lies in exploring regeneration in segmented worms. Regeneration served as a key factor for investigating sex differences in my latest project, which focuses on uncovering sex-biased differences in the segmented worm Platyneries dumerilii, using RNA sequencing. Future endeavors will center on unraveling the remarkable plasticity of segmented worm cells and their ability to undergo multiple rounds of regeneration endlessly.

title: Outreach
text:
Rapid Fire Round
Ranny currently serves as the Outreach Director of the WashU Postdoc Society (WUPS).
During her leadership, the Outreach Committee of WUPS started a series of interviews with postdocs to showcase their work and value. Many people don’t know what is to be a postdoc and by releasing these interviews we can communicute to the broaden audience and even share it with our families. Jokes apart: when discussing about this project, I was inspired by my grandparents who still thinks I am a student. She is not totally worng, because this is what scientist do the whole life: they study, but to produce knowledge. And knowledge is valuable!
You can find more about our interviews with WashU postdocs on our: Rapid Fire Round.

title: Drawings
text: These drawings were featured in some of my publications and can serve as valuable resources for teaching about segmented worms in biology.

title: Resources
text:
I like to employ different strategies for teaching. Recently, I took advantage of the flipped classroom concept and I developed some course material based on gamification. I think it is an effective approach for teaching and learning. I’ve crafted some resources for classes of Embryology, Zoology, English in three languages (Portuguese, Spanish and English). I used the platform Genially to build these games. I absolutely recommend it. Also, I published a article about my experience using some the series “Gamizoo” during lab course of Zoology. Check this and more under Publications.

Find the pairs. Embryology Course. [English]
Gamizoo Bivalvos. Zoology course. [Spanish]
Gamizoo Insectos. Zoology course. [Spanish]
Hobbying. English course. [Portuguese]
Gamizoo Aves de Navaseca. Zoology course.[Spanish]
Gamizoo Aves. Zoology course. [Spanish]

title: Resources
text:
Bioinformatics and coding resources
Helpful resources I utilize in Bioinformatics are accessible through my GitHub account.
I created this website using Quarto. It is easy and quick to manage, if you are familiar with RStudio and R coding. Theme: flatly.

title: Resources
text:
Mental Health and Professional Development
I believe that overall health should be our priority. Initially, the academic environment may pose challenges such as job insecurity, making it difficult to persevere and build resilience. Access to medical care and self-help resources is crucial. Here’s a list of my favorite resources that help me stay resilient, including books, podcasts and videos. Yes, stoicism is my lifestyle philosophy!

Letters from a Stoic, by Seneca
Meditations, by Marcus Aurelius
Amar, desamar, amar de novo, by Marcos Lacerda.
Amar-se, uma viagem em busca de si mesmo, by Marcos Lacerda.
ASMR videos. This is an amazing relaxation technique. I super recommend it.
